title: Post-Postpartum Depression
body: I suffered postpartum depression with my puppy.   It sounds like a joke, but it wasn't at the time. Riley arrived and I became a blubbering mess, overwhelmed by this creature who didn't sleep at night and seemed to poop all day. He was the final tin can in the wobbly stack of tin cans that was my life as the working mother of two young children, and his furry Wheaten face brought everything tumbling down.   Working Mother magazine has a cover story in this month's issue about depression in working mothers — more specifically, what they call post-postpartum depression.   You are back at work. You've gotten past the months where hormones are automatically blamed. You're through the colic and the round-the-clock feedings and you even have something that resembles a schedule. You fit back into your clothes, or you've faced reality and bought new ones. And then you find yourself sobbing while walking the dog.   Or, in the case of the women profiled in Working Mother, sobbing in the bathroom at work. Or in the car driving the toddlers to day care.   As the story's author, Katherine Eban, writes:   These days, most women learn about the risks of postpartum depression, the haze of new motherhood that can threaten to plunge them into a crippling, if brief, depression. About 15 percent of new mothers succumb to it, according to the National Alliance on Mental Illness. What most women don't read about in brochures in their ob-gyn's waiting room is that some of the triggers for postpartum depression — feelings of isolation and overwhelming stress — can wallop you years later. It's often their can-do qualities — juggling deadlines and diapers, deal-making and day care — that enable many working women to sail through the challenging early years of their baby's life, only to tip them into serious depression once the hardest part has passed.  The article includes a checklist from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH). If you have more than five of the symptoms, it might be wise to seek help:    A lack of interest or enjoyment in usually pleasurable activities and hobbies Feelings of hopelessness and/or pessimism  Feelings of guilt, worthlessness and/or helplessness Irritability, restlessness, anxiety Fatigue and decreased energy Decreased interest in sex Difficulty concentrating and making decisions Sleep problems, such as insomnia, wakefulness at night or excessive sleeping Overeating or appetite loss Thoughts of suicide Persistent aches or pains, or digestive problems that do not ease with treatment     One in five women will suffer depression in their lifetime, according to the NIMH, a rate that is twice that of men. And it is estimated that more than a third of women of child-bearing age suffer symptoms at any given moment.   But is that rate higher among mothers who work outside the home? The editors of Working Mother think that it is. They did an online poll of 500 working mothers last month, and 91.4 percent had felt depressed at some point since having children. (And more than half of those said it was after their baby was 3 months old or more — in other words, after the traditional postpartum period.)  Ninety-one percent. Nearly every working mother out there. Obviously an online poll of this type isn't scientific, but even so, I was surprised.   I figured the number would be higher.   p.s. I am not serious about that last sentence, of course. I would guess that 91 percent number is too high, and that women who would respond to an online survey like this are a self-selecting group. But I am also certain that there are many women who are suffering this way, most of them silently...   p.p.s.: I did get help all those years ago, in the form of medication and recommitment to getting exercise and sleep. Riley, who sits at my feet as I type this, hasn't made me cry for a very long time.

title: Postpartum Depression, Take Two
body: Heather Armstrong is pregnant again; she is due to give birth to a daughter, her second, early this summer.   Her older girl, Leta, (which rhymes with pita) just turned five, and Armstrong's book (another baby) is out this week. "It Sucked and then I Cried: How I Had a Baby, A Breakdown and a Much Needed Margarita" is a funny, irreverent look at becoming a mother. The fact that it makes you laugh so often is quite a trick, since it is about, among other things, the postpartum breakdown that led to Armstrong's stay on a psychiatric ward a few months after Leta was born.  Armstrong, who writes the wildly popular blog Dooce (which became wildly popular, in part, when she began chronicling her depression in real time years ago and followers gathered to give advice) said she was more than a little wary of having a second child given what she went through the first time around.   "There were many, many conversations and back and forth and arguments about whether we wanted to do this again," she said when we spoke by phone a few days ago. "Many, many, many, many, conversations."   She had been on anti-depression medication as a young adult, and stopped taking it in order to become pregnant with Leta. Looking back, she said, there were signs while she was pregnant of the trouble to come — a memorable "freak-out" during the torturously timed renovation of the kitchen in her ninth month comes to mind — but "I figured it was hormones, renovations are stressful, right?" she said.    After Leta was born, her despair deepened. "I was surprised," she said. "I thought it was supposed to get easier with time, but it got worse." She blamed sleep deprivation, but even when Leta began sleeping for longer stretches over the months, her mother was wide awake and crying.   At her nadir, Armstrong writes in her book, she was hurling full gallon milk jugs at her husband Jon's head. She became "so frustrated with the collapsible stroller" that she threw "it off the porch into the yard and then slammed the front door so hard that the doorknob had fallen off." Many times over the first months of her daughter's life, she continues:     I stood in front of the medicine cabinet in the kitchen trying to figure out whether or not I had the nerve to take an entire bottle of Risperdal. I thought about suicide every day during those months. I thought about how I would do it; perhaps I would hang myself with the dog's leash, or maybe I'd grab every single pill we had in the medicine cabinet and drown them with a couple of shots of tequila. I wanted to do something, anything to stop the pain.      Finally she checked herself into the hospital, on a night when the only psychiatric bed available was in the lock-down ward. A doctor she describes as her savior put her on large doses of three different medications — doses too large for a patient to take without round the clock monitoring. "He gave me enough drugs to kill a large rhinoceros," she said, "and it allowed me to sit still for the first time in seven months." That night she slept all night, for the first time since Leta had been born.   Over the years she had decreased her doses of those medications, but was still taking all three until she decided to get pregnant a second time. Two were unsafe during pregnancy. So she weaned off of those, staying only on Prozac, and keeping a close watch on her emotions for signs of trouble.   "So far so good," she says. "Jon and I talk about it constantly, he and I check in with each other every day — How am I feeling? Where is my head at?" She had flown from her home in Salt Lake City to Manhattan for the first leg of her book tour when we spoke, and when she'd arrived here the day before she'd "had a bit of a breakdown at JFK," she said. She couldn't get her suitcase off the luggage carousel and began to "lose it" when no one would offer a pregnant woman any help.   "But who doesn't have a breakdown at JFK, right?" she asked. "I didn't end up in the corner rocking back and forth, so that's progress."  After her first baby was born, Armstrong was alone all day, with no babysitter, no mommy network, and a husband who left every day for stressful work. This time around her husband is working from home and her mother is retired and ready to help. Now she has doctors to call and a therapist she sees regularly, and thousands of blog readers she can talk to every day.   "If all that doesn't work, I will go back to the hospital for help," she says. "That's the message. You can get help."    This is the time of year — as Mother's Day approaches and Father's Day follows — when there is a surge of new books about parenting. Every Friday for the next few months, at least, I will explore some of those new titles — not just the "how-tos", but also novels and memoirs and histories that touch on what it means to be a parent.
